segments.text: on the campus as a youngster, for you and your friends, did it matter what the job status of your parents was when you were at A&M-Solidarity?
I doubt if most of us even knew what our parents did or what the parents of our friends did.
We knew they were teachers, connected with the college, being paid with the college, but no, it didn't make any difference.
And I'm assuming that there was comparative continuity in those friendships because there was a comparatively stable...
Right, right.
I mean, they'd come here.
I mean, so many came here, and from whatever point they were at, when they came, they proceeded until they generally either graduated from A&M or went off someplace else.
All right, now you enrolled at A&M as a freshman in the fall of?
In the summer of 1944.
I graduated from high school on Friday night and enrolled at A&M on Monday.
That was when we were on the trimester during the war.
Okay, all right.
And, oh, well, let's back up a little bit.
How did, describe the changes that you recall at A&M after Pearl Harbor?
Well, let's see.
First thing, after Pearl Harbor, the whole class of 1942, I believe it was, 41 or 42, left en masse and went, I think, I may not be exactly right, but it seemed to me like they went to San Antonio
as a group and were inducted and then came back and finished the year and then went in the service.
I believe, I don't think that's correct.
And from then on until the war was over the student body just became fewer in number and more and more military units were taking their place.
When I entered A&M in 1944, there were less than 2,000 students in A&M.
There were probably 6,000 or 8,000 people on campus, but the rest of them were Navy or Marine or Army.
Was it V12 or something?
Where did they live?
They lived in the core area.
It was not a core area.
And the A&M students lived in the old arms.
Over on the north side?
On the north side.
Back to Pearl Harbor for a second.
Do you remember hearing that news?
I was at the campus theater on Sunday afternoon.
They stopped the movie and said that the Japanese had bombed Pearl Harbor.
Of course, most of us didn't have a clue.
I was only about 15 years old at the time.
And the one thing I remember my folks said, my mother said, well, she's glad that I was not old enough to have to go in this service.
At the time, I got to be 18.
I was playing football that fall.
My birthday's in October.
And we played out the season.
We played University of Texas on Thanksgiving.
And then on Monday, we got on the train and drove the train down to Miami and played University of Miami.
And when I got back from that trip, my dad handed me my draft notice.
And he had come before Thanksgiving, but he got it in the mail and held it until the season was over.
And I guess if he had come before Thanksgiving, it didn't take about a month or six weeks at the most from the time I turned 18.
until the time I was drafted.
And nearly everybody's in the same boat.
As soon as you turned 18, you were gone.
All right, were you deferred?
No, I wasn't deferred.
The university or the college said that if you're drafted,
Any courses that you were passing at the time, you got credit for them without finishing the semester.
So then you go on active duty when?
Well, I went on active duty in January of 1945.
All right, so let's go back.
So you're here from the summer of?
Summer of 1944 through January of 1945.
The football team that fall that you were with, were most of them freshmen and sophomores?
Really a large majority were freshmen.
There were a few sophomores.
The year before was the Kiddie Corps team that was nearly all 17 year olds.
And we had
two or three guys, Bullet Gray that I mentioned, and Bob Buchovsky, and Monty Mongrief, that were veterinary students.
And they had gotten deferred?
They were deferred in order to finish veterinary school.
And we had three or four, I can't remember, at least three.
And then we had two or three guys that did discharge for one reason or another and came back.
And then there were some that had played the year before that evidently were so young that they were able to make it through their sophomore year.
But nearly all of us, nearly all of us, before the war was over, we called into service.
I'm not going to ask you who, if there is an answer to this question.
Did you know of any person, were you acquainted with anybody, who attempted to evade?
That's my memory, too.
I don't know of anybody.
I'm sure there were some, but those guys that were in vet school, veterinary medicine school, I don't think they were evaded.
in vet school because most of them were seniors.
And they would have had to anticipate.
Where did you live that summer and fall?
I lived at home.
Oh, you lived at home.
And you took full load academically.
What was your major?
It was undeclared at the time.
I guess pretty much all took the same thing.
Nearly all of my classes, the role was alphabetical.
A's through C's were in there.
I was with that group nearly all the way.
Aren't you in your reported active duty when?
January.

and you left by the train on bus bus we were reported to the draft office in dubai and we got on the bus we went to houston we were inducted in houston the coach on the train and sent us to san antonio one interested that was one of the guys that i met the morning that we reported for the draft was a
a guy that had graduated from Bryan High School.
His name's Ray Copas.
I don't know if you know Ray or not, but anyway, we rode the bus together down to Houston.
They shipped us to Fort Hood, Camp Hood.
We were in the same platoon.
In fact, in the same squad.
My name's Cash, and his name was Copas, and we were close enough
We were in the same squad in basic training.
When the war in Europe was over, they said that 18-year-olds had to be in the service six months.
And so they sent us down to Camp Rucker, Alabama.
And we stayed down there until August of 1945.
And they shipped us to Fort Ord.
And we were on the ship two days out of Fort Ord when they dropped the atom bomb.
How did you hear about that?
I don't know.
They just started talking about it.
Because the war was over by the time we got overseas.
How did you guys react when you heard the war was over?
Well, you know, there wasn't much we could do except just holler and hoot.
But Ray and I,
Staying together, they shipped us to the Philippines, and from the Philippines to Korea.
We were in Korea a year, and they shipped us home.
And we rode the bus from San Antonio to Dubai to get to America.
So we were roommates the whole time we were in Korea.
Ray, after we both went back in the Corps, when we got back in there and got our commissions,
when the Korean War started about 10 days after I graduated.
But we were already committed to two years.
But he transferred his commission to the Air Force and made a career.
I got out quick as I could.
His last duty station was A&M.
and he retired here and we played golf together three days a week.
Back before you leave, the first time, do you remember anything said by your parents the night before or as you go to the bus or anything?
I remember my parents were
strangely quiet.
They didn't say much.
I remember the morning that we got up early, they had to be over there at 6 o'clock or something.
But it was a whole lot more traumatic for them than it was for me, I'm sure.
I didn't much care.
Let's see, other things.
Do you remember where you were when you heard that President Roosevelt had died?
No.
Let's see.
That was in, what, April of 45?
Mm-hmm.
I was in Fort Wood.
I was in basic training in Fort Wood.
I don't remember my reaction much.
I was in the shower, spring training in high school.
Oh, really?
And we thought some guy was trying to play a joke.
And we said, hey, that's not funny.
And he said, no, it's the truth.
When I got home, I realized I hadn't even dried off.
I put my clothes on, wet.
And all the way home, we were talking about, wonder who the president will be, because President Roosevelt had been the only president we could remember.
Yeah.
But I don't remember much reaction.
I do remember we were on our way from Camp Rucker to Fort Howard on the train when we heard that they had stopped gas racing.
And I remember that because all during the time we were in high school.
We got four gallons of gas a week, and we couldn't do much, you know, four gallons.
All right, so you get back to A&M in the fall of 46?
46, yeah.
Describe A&M then.
Then it was bustling, man.
And the strange thing was to see so many people not in uniform.
Because, you know, to me,
you're an Aggie, you wore a uniform.
And when we got back, why, most of the guys were not in the Corps.
There were more veterans here than there were non-veterans.
And there was a distinct gap between the veterans and non-veterans.
Age-wise, motivation-wise, a lot of them were married.
It was just, I mean, it was
Two camps all together.
All right.
Now, did you go back into the Corps?
Yeah, I went back into the Corps.
I went one semester.
Taylor Wilkins was the veterans advisor.
And he got to be good buddies with a whole bunch of us college kids and bride kids.
I'm not sure exactly why or who started it.
I think Ellie Wynder won it.
But anyway, Taylor Whitman had a big influence on us, and he taught several of us.
He just said, you're going to be sorry if you get your permission.
So we got back in the Corps, and because of the extra hours that we had to take in order to finish our military, it cost me extra semesters.
So instead of graduating in January of 1950, I graduated in June.
So you go back in the Corps as a sophomore?
Well, no, I went back and we got credit for the first two years.
Oh, first two years, okay.
Because we were in the service.
So I went back in.

under contract okay uh and did where did you live then about here so you lived at home all four years right uh about uh where were where was this big crowd of students living well of course the the dorms were all full and then they built they built was the college view you know you know the they moved the
barracks and built for the marriage students.
And then the all the project houses have been converted to marriage student quarters.
Were there some house trailers also?
Oh yeah, I was just in addition to the project houses, the whole area that's now the parking lot for the stadium and for the tennis courts, it was all
But it was all on the east side of the Weldron Road.
There were a few houses right immediately beyond the Weldron Road.
They had been there.
People that worked on the A&M Farms and so on lived in them.
And I'm not sure.
There may have been some students living in some of those.
But they lived just about everywhere.
I don't know where they could find that place.
All right.
Describe, compare the attitude you had as a student when you came back with the attitude you had when you first began.
Well, when I first began, I mean, the uppermost thing in my mind was .
Except my dad, I mean,
He said, if you don't make your grades, you can't play.
And he was paying the bill at that point.
I remember Coach Norton asked me if I was going to play football that summer.
And I said, no, I didn't think I was.
And he wondered why.
And I said, well, I didn't think I was big enough.
He said, well, you've got a uniform that'll fit you.
It's not for you to come out.
That's what I wanted to do, you know.
And so I went out for football, and there were about 100 of us or so that went out for football.
And it was just like high school.
Anybody wanted to play.
And there were a few guys on scholarship.
So in today's terminology, that first fall, you were a walk-on back in 44.
I walked on.
And I remember that they, I'm sure the guys that were on scholarship,
I didn't know what a scholarship was.
I never even heard of a scholarship.
But the ones that were on scholarship, they practiced.
When we first started that summer, they were practicing on the practice field that was right by the stadium.
I was way over at the baseball field.
And I don't even remember who was coaching us, because they only had three or four coaches.
And I don't know who was even coaching us, but I kept getting moved up, moved up.
And finally, by the time the first game came around, I was starting.
So you, as a walk-on, were a starter.
First game.
And you weighed about how much?
What was your position?
Quarterback.
Quarterback.
And you all were running the?
We were running the T formation.
The first time we started everybody.
I think he just played.
He was just having an enjoyable time trying something new.
In the lingo of that day, it was the tight tee, not the splint.
Then when you come back...
When we came back... Back to this attitude.
Well, I still want to play football, and that didn't change until...
We played LSU.
My sophomore year, I broke my leg.
And after that, football wasn't near as important.
All I could think about was getting out.
And I wanted to coach.
And I just wanted to get through the school and get going.
Well, then when I got through the school, the war started and they called me back in the service.
And so I went back in the service.

when I got back out two years later and back and that Taylor Wilkins gave me a job as a military counselor said I could work on my master's degree as soon as I got it well I went to West Texas and started coaching.
And that you began coaching what year?

all right uh let's go back to the when you come back in 46. uh you had to declare a major somewhere along the way what well i physical education because i definitely i wanted to coach that's what i want to do as you now look back on all of those undergraduate years who were the key teachers or advisors or counselors that made a difference there was uh
There was a biology prof. Let me see what his name was.
I didn't think I'd ever forget his name.
Anyway, he taught anatomy and physiology.
And most of us that were in the class were PE majors.
But he did the best job teaching.
I'm just getting material across to him.
And he was so patient with us, you know.
And I just, I thought he was one of the best professors I ever had.
Dr. Keel was an English teacher, I believe.
And I thought a lot of him.
What was the history teacher that went to East Texas?
Ralph Steen.
Ralph Steen.
I thought he was marvelous.
What made him so good?
He was just entertaining.
I had his class Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday at 8 o'clock.
And I never missed it.
Because I just enjoyed learning it.
He made Texas history something beside dates.
I'm surprised to hear you say that about him.
He'd come in in the morning and all he'd have was his grade book.
And he'd check the roll and then he'd start talking and he'd refer to a passage that he had assigned or something.
Let's see.
Another teacher that made a...
impact on me, but it was negative, was Square Root Jackson.
Did you ever have Square Root?
No, but I heard the legend that he was hard, hard to pass.
Well, he did so many, he was such a mathematician, I suppose, that he never could get on the
especially at first year algebra.
I was taking trig under him.
And up until that point, I'd never made anything but an A in math.
And I remember we got, I was just barely hanging on by the skin of my teeth when we left to go to Miami at Thanksgiving.
And he would come in and he would say,

okay open your book to sudden sets we're gonna work these problems and he'd like that i mean he had the book memorized he didn't even look at the book he'd write the problems on the board and he'd work them so fast and he was with no explanation and i was i was really i was really thinking about being a math teacher until that one semester with him
He just destroyed my confidence as far as math's concerned.
I still would like to be a math teacher.
If I had to do over, that's what I'd teach.
I wish I could think of that man's name, though, because he taught biology here for a long time.
Any non-instructional counselors, advisors?
Well, we always thought a lot of Spike White.
What did Spike do?
Spike was...
Well, at one point he ran a mural program.
And then he was director of student services or something.
I'm not sure what it was.
He was just a friend.
Kind of like Mr. Penny Pembroke.
There were so many of those guys that were here before I left.
that were my dad's peers.
And because of that relationship, I had a special relationship with Dr. Gammon and Mr. Penberthy and Dean Bolton and Gib Gilchrist.
They were family friends as well as professional friends.
And you couldn't keep from being influenced by those people.
And I'm assuming also that was a pretty good restraint on any kind of...
There was no thought of, you know, of trying to get by with something.
Of mischief.
Because you weren't going to.
I mean, it was just... You know, I've often thought that maybe I'd have been a whole lot better off down the line if I'd gone off someplace else.
And, you know, you never know.
You can't second guess, but...
Now you, when you came back after the war, were you on scholarship and the GI Bill?
I was on scholarship and the GI Bill and a military contract.
Okay.
Oh, you had some money then.
I had more money, more money to spend my last two years in Indiana than I've ever had since.
Did you live at home?
I lived at home and my scholarship
was a check for $60 a month.
OK. Now I'm thinking about the parental changes.
How did your mother and dad differ, if they did, in the advice and counsel they gave you after the war before?
Well, they pretty much left me alone, as far as
They didn't look down my throat or anything like that.
But I knew that they were there.
And I wasn't going to do anything that would discredit them.
You had a car.
Well, I did the last year.
The last year.
You couldn't buy a car.
Oh, that's right.
Sure.
You couldn't buy a car.
So I got my name on the list.
And just before my senior year,
My aunt that lived across the street had, she had her name on the list up at Will's Point all during the war.
Well, her name came up and she said, well, you can buy that parking lot.
I had saved enough money from- What kind of car was it?
1948 Chevrolet, two door.
How long did you keep it?
I kept it until 1950.
I swapped it for a Buick.
Remember what you paid for it?
I paid $1,400.
Wow.
Cash.
Yeah.
Now, after you hurt your leg, did you play?
I hurt my leg, I think it was the fourth game my sophomore year.
So I had to finish layout that year.
And then I had gained so much weight.
I never was the fastest guy in the world.
And so after I came back, I never couldn't run much.
And I played two more years.
But it was just kind of off and on.
And my attitude wasn't as good as it should have been as far as it wasn't the same.
I'll put it that way.
And I got caught up like everybody else that was in my situation.
There was a
the coaching staff was trying to recruit the young guys and they brought them in.
We had Glenn Lipman and that bunch that were freshmen, my junior year.
And there was, if they treated everybody like veterans, the freshmen weren't getting what they needed.
And if they treated us like incoming freshmen, there was just a big gap between them.
And so,
It was really a trying time as far as athletics is concerned.
Coach Norton is here through your... Sophomore year.
Sophomore year.
I played for... Steitler?
Steitler.
Describe Coach Norton as a coach, as a person.
Well, Coach Norton was my eye as far as coaching was concerned, you know.
And he and Manning Smith, Manning Smith was the backfield coach.

And from the time I began to move up far enough where there was a chance that I might get the play, I spent an hour or so every day at this coach's office with the other guys that were going to be quarterbacks.
